member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStateEventHandler
member.summary: The ConnectionStateEventHandler delegate represents the method that will be called when the phone book Entry state changes.
member.example:
The following example shows how the delegate can be used to track the state of the dial up connection.
Imports PsionTeklogix.RAS
Public Sub DialEntry(name As String) Dim entry as Entry dim pb As New Phonebook
entry = pb.Entry(name)
' Dial asyncronously entry.Dial(False, AddressOf(OnStateChange)) End Sub
' Callback function for state changes Private Sub OnStateChange(sender As Object, e As ConnectionStateEventArgs) ' Inform the user that the connection has been established. If e.State = ConnectionStates.Connected Then MessageBox.Show("The Connection has been established") End If End Sub

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates
member.summary: This enumeration type contains values that specify the states that may occur during a RAS connection operation. If you use the Dial method to establish a RAS connection, you can specify a callback to receive state changes for the current connection state. You can also use the ConnectionStatus method to get the connection state.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.OpenPort
member.summary: The communication port is about to be opened.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.PortOpened
member.summary: The communication port has been opened successfully.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.ConnectDevice
member.summary: A device is about to be connected. RasGetConnectStatus can be called to determine the name and type of the device being connected.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.DeviceConnected
member.summary: A device has connected successfully.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.AllDevicesConnected
member.summary: All devices in the device chain have successfully connected. At this point, the physical link is established.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.Authenticate
member.summary: The authentication process is starting. Remote access does not enable the remote client to generate any traffic on the LAN until authentication has been successfully completed.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.AuthChangePassword

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.AuthProject

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.AuthLinkSpeed
member.summary: The link-speed calculation phase is starting.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.AuthAck
member.summary: An authentication request is being acknowledged.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.ReAuthenticate
member.summary: Reauthentication (after callback) is starting.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.Authenticated
member.summary: The client has successfully completed authentication.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.PrepareForCallback
member.summary: The line is about to disconnect in preparation for callback.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.WaitForModemReset
member.summary: The client is delaying in order to give the modem time to reset itself in preparation for callback.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.WaitForCallback
member.summary: The client is waiting for an incoming call from the remote access server.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.ConnectionStates.Projected
member.summary: This state occurs after the AuthProject state. It indicates that projection result data is available.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.Pattern
member.summary: The Pattern class is used to configure blink patterns of an LED. A pattern works as follows: colour1 is displayed for a length of time equal to duration1Milliseconds. colour2 is displayed for a length of time equal to duration2Milliseconds. The above sequence (1, 2) is repeated repeatCount times. There will then be a delay of delayMilliseconds.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.Pattern.colour1
member.summary: The first LED colour to display in the pattern.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.Pattern.duration1Milliseconds
member.summary: The duration of the first part of the pattern (duration that we want colour1 to display).

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.Pattern.colour2
member.summary: The second LED colour to display in the pattern.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.Pattern.duration2Milliseconds
member.summary: The duration of the second part of the pattern (duration that we want colour2 to display).

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.Pattern.repeatCount
member.summary: The number of times to repeat the colour1/colour2 sequence.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.Pattern.delayMilliseconds
member.summary: The delay in milliseconds between two successive runs of a pattern.

summary.p: The LED class is used to control access to the LEDs present on a Psion Teklogix device. Almost every Psion Teklogix device has one or more LEDs that are available for use by applications, be they developed by Psion Teklogix, or by 3rd-party developers. Applications typically use the LEDs to indicate device activity, data reception / transmission, error conditions, alerts, and software updates, among other things.

In order to access a LED, an application needs to first list the LEDs available on the current device through a call to the EnumerateLEDs method. The LED class will return an array containing all of the LEDs available to the application, though some of the LEDs returned may not actually be available for use (see below). If no LEDs are returned, the device does not have any available for use.

The application may then attempt to instantiate a LED object via one of the two GetLEDInstance methods. If successful, the LED object may then be used to control the LED selected. Note: the GetLEDInstance method will throw an exception if LED is already in use by another application. The other application will have to be terminated in order to allow this application to access the LED.

Once instantiated, the following operations can be executed by the LED object: * Changing the colour - The SetColour method can be used to turn a LED on or off, or on devices with multi-colour LEDs, change the LED colour. * Pulse the LED - The Pulse method can be used to briefly change the colour of the LED, overriding other operations being performed on the LED. * Blink in a pattern - The SetPattern method can be used to blink the LED on and off, or blink in different colours (on / off, red / green). The length of time the colours are displayed, and the repeat count/rate can be configured.

remarks.p: An LED must be disposed of when an application is finished using it (using the Dispose method). Failure to dispose of the LED object before an application terminates may prevent other applications from using the LED on some platforms.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.LED.EnumerateLEDs

member.returns: The EnumerateLEDs method returns an array of strings giving the names of the LEDs available for use by an application.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.LED.GetLEDInstance
member.summary: Returns the default LED instance to the caller. If no LEDs have been instantiated, creates LED objects for all available LEDs, and returns the first available LED instance to the caller (the default LED). If no LEDs are available, an exception will be thrown.
member.returns: Returns the default LED instance (if an LED is available) throw Exception if no LEDs are available.
member.exception: Thrown if no LEDs are available.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.LED.GetLEDInstance(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the specified LED instance to the caller. If the LED instance associated with the specified name has not previously allocated, the method will first attempt to create the instance, and if successful will return the LED instance to the caller. If the LED could not be allocated, an exception will be thrown.
member.param: The name of the LED to allocate, must be one of the LED names returned by the EnumerateLEDs() method.
member.returns: Returns the default LED instance .

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.LED.GetSoftwareLEDInstance(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the default LED instance to the caller.
member.param: The name of the LED to allocate, must be one of the LED names returned by the EnumerateLEDs() method.
member.returns: Returns the default LED instance (if an LED is available) throws RuntimeException if no LEDs are available.

member.name: P:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.LED.pattern
member.summary: Gets/Sets the pattern displayed by the LED. An LED pattern is when the LED is asked to blink on and off (or between colours X and Y) an certain number times, with the LED turned on/off/set to certain colour for a given length of time. Patterns can be used to indicate some event is taking place, such as a software update, data reception, operation in progress, etc. Patterns are specified in a pattern object, see the Pattern class, above.
member.exception: Thrown if the LED object was in the middle of GC.

member.name: P:PsionTeklogix.Indicators.LED.colour
member.summary: Gets/Sets colour property Sets the colour of the LED to the specified colour, cancelling any pattern in progress. Once the call to this method completes, the pattern information will report an infinite duration for colour1, with no repetitions.
member.exception: Thrown if the LED object was in the middle of GC.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Barcode.ScannerServices.EnhancedViewfinderControl
member.summary: @deprecated Will be replaced by Imager SDK and namespace. The EnhancedViewfinderControl creates a image viewfinder 'window' in an application. The viewfinder control, once enabled, will display the current image being captured by the imager. The image will be updated periodically (approximately every 100 to 200ms).

remarks.p: The enhanced viewfinder control operates on an ImageCaptureDevice object supplied by the application. If the application is using an ImageCaptureDevice control, it can get the internal ImageCaptureDevice object used by the control using the 'ImageCaptureDevice' property.

The viewfinder does not take over or otherwise prevent other code from using the imager, nor does it reconfigure the imager. Consequently, the viewfinder control will always use the current imager configuration, and will be affected by any changes made to it. Do note however that it may not be possible to capture an image while the imager is in viewfinder mode.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Barcode.ScannerServices.EnhancedViewfinderControl.#ctor
member.summary: @deprecated This class will be replaced by Imager SDK and namespace. Constructor for the EnhancedViewfinderControl class.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Barcode.ScannerServices.EnhancedViewfinderControl.Dispose
member.summary: @deprecated This class will be replaced by Imager SDK and namespace. Releases all resources used by the Component.

remarks.p: Calling Dispose allows the resources used by the Component to be reallocated for other purposes.
The Dispose method does not release the resources held by the ImageCaptureDevice object referenced by the ImageCaptureDevice property.

member.exception: ObjectDisposedException - If the ImageCaptureDevice object has already been disposed.

member.name: P:PsionTeklogix.Barcode.ScannerServices.EnhancedViewfinderControl.EnableViewfinder
member.summary: @deprecated This class will be replaced by Imager SDK and namespace. The EnableViewfinder property enables or disables the viewfinder window. While enabled, the viewfinder will capture images from imager and show them in the display area of the component.

remarks.p: Setting this property to true has no effect if the ImageCaptureDevice property is null.

member.exception: ObjectDisposedException - If the ImageCaptureDevice object has already been disposed.

member.name: P:PsionTeklogix.Barcode.ScannerServices.EnhancedViewfinderControl.ImageCaptureDevice

remarks.p: The viewfinder control does not change or otherwise reconfigure the imager.
It is not possible to enable the viewfinder until this property is set to a valid non-null value.
Use the ImageCaptureDeviceControl.ImageCaptureDevice property to get a valid value for this property if an application is not working directly with ImageCaptureDevice objects.

member.exception: ObjectDisposedException - If the ImageCaptureDevice object has already been disposed.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties
member.summary: Defines the properties of a RAS phonebook entry.
member.remarks: The RasEntryProperties class is used to store the configuration of a RAS phonebook entry, including information to determine: * How to generate the phone number to dial * What device should be used to dial to the server * Extra information to provide to the server * The authentication protocols that can and can't be negotiated * The framing protocol and frame size to use * Script name * AutoDialing configuration * Network configuration (WINS, DNS, local IP address)

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_USE_COUNTRY_AND_AREA_CODES
member.summary: If this flag is set, the country code and area code members will be used to construct the phone number dialed. If the option is not enabled, the country code and area code members are ignored. This flag is equivalent to the 'Use Country / Region and Area Codes' checkbox found on the phone dialog box.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_SPECIFIC_IPADDR
member.summary: Allows a specific IP address to be configured for the dial-up connection. The IP address to use must be set in the RasEntryProperties.ipAddress member, below. Setting this flag corresponds to checking the 'Specify an IP Address' checkbox on the TCP/IP Settings dialog box. If specified, the IP address will override the one set in the Network Control Panel.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_SPECIFIC_NAME_SERVERS
member.summary: If this flag is enabled, the DNS, alternate DNS, WINS and alternate WINS server IP addresses may be specified (below). This flag corresponds to the checkbox 'Specify Name Server Addresses' on the TCP/IP Settings dialog box.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_IPHEADER_COMPRESSION
member.summary: If this flag is set, RAS tries to negotiate the use of IP header compression on the PPP connection. If not set, IP header compression is not negotiated. This flag should be set, as it can significantly improve performance on slower connections. Note that it may have to be cleared when communicating with some older RAS servers that do not correctly negotiate or support IP header compression

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_REMOTE_DEFAULT_GATEWAY
member.summary: Windows CE enables this option when a new RAS entry is created and populated with default values. It is subsequently ignored, and does not modify the default route.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_DISABLE_LCP_EXTENSIONS
member.summary: If this flag is set, RAS disables the PPP LCP extensions defined in RFC 1570. However, setting the flag may uinterfere with RAS features such as server callback. It is recommended that this option should be left disabled unless it is required.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_SW_COMPRESSION
member.summary: If this flag is set, the RAS server and client will attempt to negotiate the use of software compression (CCP) on the PPP link. This option should be enabled for most connections, but may be disabled to reduce negotiation times if the server and client do not have a common, compatible compression protocol.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_REQUIRE_ENCRYPTED_PW
member.summary: If this option is enabled, only secure password schemes may be used to authenticate the user, meaning that PAP cannot be used, as the password is sent as plain text under PAP. SPAP and CHAP may be used, however. Note that setting this flag may limit uinteroperability with older servers. This flag corresponds to the 'Require Encrypted Password' check box in the Security dialog box.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_REQUIRE_MS_ENCRYPTED_PW
member.summary: If this option is enabled, only the Microsoft Challenge Authentication Protocol (MSCHAP) may be used to authenticate a user. PAP and MD5-CHAP may not be used. This flag overrides the OPT_REQUIRE_ENCRYPTED_PW flag. The option corresponds to the Require Microsoft Encrypted Password check box in the Security dialog box.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_REQUIRE_DATA_ENCRYPTION
member.summary: This option forces the client and server to successfully negotiate data encryption, and close the connection if it cannot be negotiated. This flag is ignored if the OPT_REQUIRE_MS_ENCRYPTED_PW option is not enabled. The OPT_REQUIRE_DATA_ENCRYPTION flag corresponds to the Require Data Encryption check box in the Security dialog box.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_NETWORK_LOGON
member.summary: If this option is enabled, RAS will attempt to log on to the network after the connection to the server has been established.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_USE_LOGON_CREDENTIALS
member.summary: This flag causes RAS to use the same user name, domain and password of the currently logged-on user when dialing a connection. The flag will be ignored unless the OPT_REQUIRE_MS_ENCRYPTED_PW flag is also set. This setting is ignored by the RasEntry.Dial method, where specifying empty strings for the user name, password and domain has the same effect.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_DIAL_AS_LOCAL_CALL
member.summary: If this option is enabled, RAS generates the phone number as a local call. It will include the area code if the area code does not match the area code of the current location. The flag is equivalent to the "force local" option in various RAS-related dialog boxes.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_PROHIBIT_PAP
member.summary: If this flag is set, PAP (Password Authentication Protocol) will not be used. If not set, the use of PAP may be negotiated.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_PROHIBIT_CHAP
member.summary: If this flag is set, CHAP (Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol) will not be used. If not set, the use of CHAP may be negotiated.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_PROHIBIT_MSCHAP
member.summary: If this flag is set, MSCHAP (Microsoft Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol) will not be used. If not set, the use of MSCHAP may be negotiated.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_PROHIBIT_MSCHAP2
member.summary: If this flag is set, MSCHAP v2.0 (Microsoft Challenge Handshake Authentication Protocol) will not be used. If not set, the use of MSCHAP v2.0 may be negotiated.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_PROHIBIT_EAP
member.summary: If this flag is set, use of the Extensible Authentication Protocol will not be allowed. If not set, EAP may be negotiated. Note: currently, the Java RAS API does does support EAP. This flag should always be set.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_PREVIEW_USERPW
member.summary: If this option is set, RAS will display a username/password dialog before attempting to connect to the RAS server. Note that this is not the same dialog as the one that appears when the RasEntry.Dial(true) method is invoked.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_CUSTOM_SCRIPT
member.summary: If enabled, this flag will cause RAS to to invoke the custom-scripting specified below DLL after establishing a connection to the server.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_TERMINAL_BEFORE_DIAL
member.summary: This flag is not currently supported by Windows CE

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_TERMINAL_AFTER_DIAL
member.summary: This flag is not currently supported by Windows CE

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_MODEM_LIGHTS
member.summary: This flag is not currently supported by Windows CE

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_PROMOTE_ALTERNATES
member.summary: This flag is not currently supported by Windows CE

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.OPT_SECURE_LOCAL_FILES
member.summary: If this option is enabled, it forces RAS to check for remote printer and file system bindings, that is those created as a result of enabling Printer and File Sharing.

remarks.p: This option should be set when connecting to a public network to notify users to disconnect existing network connections (i.e. to private networks) before establishing a connection the public network.

If either Client for Microsoft Networks or File and Print Sharing is not enabled on a given connection, calling RasEntry.GetEntryProperties returns with the OPT_SECURE_LOCAL_FILES flag set. Calling RasEntry.SetEntryProperties with the OPT_SECURE_LOCAL_FILES set disabled both Client for Microsoft Networks and File and Print Sharing; disabling the option enables both items.
This option is not currently supported by Windows CE.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.PROTO_PPP
member.summary: Use PPP (the Point-to-Point Protocol - RFC 1661) as the framing protocol

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.PROTO_SLIP
member.summary: Use SLIP (the Serial Line IP Protocol - RFC 1055) as the framing protocol

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.FRAME_SIZE_1006
member.summary: Use a frame size of 1006 when communicating with the RAS Server.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.FRAME_SIZE_1500
member.summary: Use a frame size of 1500 when communicating with the RAS Server.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.DEVTYPE_DIRECT
member.summary: Direct Connect (WINCE Extension)

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.DEVTYPE_MODEM
member.summary: Modem connection

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.DEVTYPE_ISDN
member.summary: ISDN

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.DEVTYPE_VPN
member.summary: Virtual Private Network (Point-to-Point Tunnelling Protocol)

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.DEVTYPE_PPPOE
member.summary: Point-to-Point Protocol over Ethernet

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.options
member.summary: The options to use when connecting and negotiation connection options. By default, Software Compression and IP header compression should be enabled. EAP negotiation must be disabled (not supported).

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.countryCode
member.summary: The country/region portion of the phone number dialed. This setting will be ignored unless the OPT_USE_COUNTRY_AND_AREA_CODES option is enabled.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.areaCode
member.summary: The area code portion of the phone number, without brackets or other delimiters. This setting will be ignored unless the OPT_USE_COUNTRY_AND_AREA_CODES option is enabled.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.localPhoneNumber
member.summary: The phone number to dial. Its use will depend on the options set above. If the OPT_USE_COUNTRY_AND_AREA_CODES option is enabled, the phone number will be assembled from the country code and area code. If not set, or if the OPT_DIAL_AS_LOCAL_CALL option is set, the entire string will be used as the phone number.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.ipAddress
member.summary: The IP address to assign to the Psion Teklogix device. This parameter is ignored unless the OPT_SPECIFIC_IPADDR option is enabled

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.ipAddressDns
member.summary: The DNS server IP address for the Psion Teklogix device. This parameter is ignored unless the OPT_SPECIFIC_NAME_SERVERS option is enabled

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.ipAddressDnsAlt
member.summary: The alternate DNS server IP address for the Psion Teklogix device. This parameter is ignored unless the OPT_SPECIFIC_NAME_SERVERS option is enabled

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.ipAddressWins
member.summary: The WINS server IP address for the Psion Teklogix device. This parameter is ignored unless the OPT_SPECIFIC_NAME_SERVERS option is enabled

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.ipAddressWinsAlt
member.summary: The alternate WINS server IP address for the Psion Teklogix device. This parameter is ignored unless the OPT_SPECIFIC_NAME_SERVERS option is enabled

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.framingProtocol
member.summary: The protocol to use when communicating with the server. PPP is the most common protocol used, although SLIP is used frequently in UNIX environments.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.frameSize
member.summary: The frame size to use when communicating with the RAS Server. This option is only useful when "SLIP" is being used.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.script
member.summary: The name of the RAS script file. The script should be specified as a full path

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.autoDialDll
member.summary: The full name and path of the DLL used as the customized AutoDial handler. If the name is an empty string, the default auto-dialer is used.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.autoDialFunc
member.summary: The name of the auto-dial function in the AutoDial handler. The DLL must provide both the ANSI and Unicode version of the RASADFunc function. The A or W suffix must not be specified in the AutoDial function name.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.deviceType
member.summary: The type of the TAPI device the RAS connection will use. The names and types of all available devices can be found using the RasPhonebook.EnumerateRasDevices method.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.deviceName
member.summary: The name of the TAPI device the RAS connection will use. The names and types of all available devices can be found using the RasPhonebook.EnumerateRasDevices method.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.x25PadType
member.summary: The X.25 pad type. This parameter must be an empty string unless an X.25 PAD device or native X.25 device is going to be used when dialing.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.x25Address
member.summary: The X.25 address to connect to. This parameter must be an empty string unless an X.25 PAD device or native X.25 device is going to be used when dialing.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.x25Facilities
member.summary: The X.25 facilities to request from the server. This parameter must be an empty string unless an X.25 PAD device or native X.25 device is going to be used when dialing.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.x25UserData
member.summary: Addition X.25 data to send to the host when connected. This parameter must be an empty string unless an X.25 PAD device or native X.25 device is going to be used when dialing.

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties.channels
member.summary: Specifies the number of channels supported by the device (1 = mono, 2 = stereo, and so on).

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook
member.summary: Represents the RAS Phonebook.
member.remarks: Note: that there are no properties or methods for managing Phonebook but there is an alternative way to manage these entries. As the phone book is stored in the registry under HKEY_CURRENT_USER\Comm\Rasphone, it is suggested that the entries be created during development and exported using the Remote Regedit tool. These entries may then be added during the installtion procedure by editing the .inf file used to create the installtion cab file.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook.RasPhoneBook
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the Phonebook class.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook.EnumerateDevices
member.summary: Enumerates all available RAS devices.
member.returns: The names of all available RAS devices

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook.EnumerateRasDevices
member.summary: Returns all available RAS devices and their types.
member.returns: The names and types of all available RAS devices.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook.Refresh
member.summary: Refreshes an instance of the Phonebook class.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook.GetEntry(System.String)
member.summary: Gets the specified entry.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook.AddEntry(System.String)
member.summary: Returns all of the devices that can be used to create a RAS connection on the Psion Teklogix device.
member.remarks: This method is obsolete.
member.param: Ras entry name
member.exception: Always. This method is obsolete.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook.AddEntry(System.String,PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasEntryProperties)
member.summary: Adds a new entry to the RAS phonebook. The name for the new entry must be valid, and must not match the name of an existing entry. The properties specified must also be valid.
member.remarks: * Certain values in the RasEntryProperties object will be ignored unless the appropriate option is set (for example, area code will be ignored unless the use country and area codes flag is set). * Similarly, the X.25 settings will be ignored unless an X.25 device is present and selected as the RAS device. * See the Win32 API documentation of 'RasValidateEntryName' for the rules for naming a RAS entry.
member.param: Ras entry name to add.
Ras entry properties
member.exception: If the entry name and/or properties are null.
If the entry name is invalid or already exists.
If the entry cannot be created.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook.RemoveEntry(System.String)
member.summary: Removes Entry from Entries collection
member.param: Ras Entry Name

member.summary: Gets a collection of entries in the Phonebook.

member.name: P:PsionTeklogix.RAS.RasPhonebook.Connections
member.summary: Gets a collection of entries that are connected.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard
member.summary: The keyboard class allows developers to: -Determine if a hardware keyboard is present on the current Psion Teklogix device. -Determine other information about the keyboard (type, etc.), and to disable and re-enable the keyboard when necessary. -The Keyboard class also allows the simulation of keyboard events in software, and to translate between virtual-key codes and scan codes. -Monitor modifier keys events (when blue, orange, shift, alt and control keys are pressed).
member.remarks:
The hardware keyboard is the physical keyboard which is part of the device. The software keyboard is any SIP device.
The keyboard class wraps a number of functions available in the Windows CE Win32 APIs. They are provided here as part of this assembly for your convenience. For detailed information on these APIs, please consult the Microsoft documentation for Windows CE .NET located here: .
You can also navigate to these functions in MSDN by following this path: Mobile and Embedded Development > Embedded Operating System Development > Windows CE > Windows CE .NET > Product Documentation Application Development > User Interface Services > User Interface Reference > Keyboard Reference > Keyboard Functions Note: Disabling the keyboard is dangerous, and care should be taken to make sure the keyboard is disabled only when absolutely necessary!

member.name: F:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.ScanCodeNotFound
member.summary: TranslateToScanCode will return this constant if the specified key doesn't have a scancode in a particular device.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.GetKeyboardType
member.summary: Determines the keyboard type on the Psion Teklogix device.

remarks.p: Currently, the keyboard type is a string representing the name of the country or language with which it is associated, or a count of the number of keys on the device.

One of the following names will be returned: * United Kingdom * United States * French * German * Italian * Spanish * ABC-Key * Azerty-Key * Qwerty-Key * 24 Key Keyboard * 36-Key * 37-Key * 52 Key Keyboard * 56-Key * 58-Key * 62-Key * None * Unknown

member.returns: The type of keyboard, as a string.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.GetAsyncKeyState(System.Int16)
member.summary: Determines whether a key is up or down at the time the function is called, and whether the key was pressed after a previous call to GetAsyncKeyState.
member.param: [in] Specifies one of 256 possible virtual-key codes.

returns.para: If the method succeeds, the return value specifies whether the key was pressed since the last call to GetAsyncKeyState, and whether the key is currently up or down. If the most significant bit is set, the key is down. The least significant bit is not valid in Windows CE, and should be ignored. GetAsyncKeyState returns the current key state even if a window in another thread or process currently has the keyboard focus.
This method wraps the GetAsyncKeyState() function in the Windows CE APIs. For more detailed information, please consult MSDN documentation at .

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.keybd_event(System.Byte,System.Byte,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Synthesizes a keystroke. The system can use such a synthesized keystroke to generate a WM_KEYUP or WM_KEYDOWN message.
member.param: [in] Specifies a virtual-key code. The code must be a value in the range 1 to 254.
[in] Specifies a hardware scan code for the key. This parameter is not explicitly used.
[in] Flags which specify various aspects of function operation.
[in] Specifies an additional 32-bit value associated with the key stroke.
member.remarks: This method wraps the keybd_event function in the Windows CE APIs. For detailed information, including flag values for the dwFlags parameter, please see the MSDN documentation for this function at .

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.EnableHardwareKeyboard(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables the hardware keyboard.
member.remarks:
This method affects only the hardware keyboard - that is, the physical keyboard that is an integral part of the device - and external keyboards, or virtual keyboards displayed on the touch-sensitive screen.
It is sometimes desirable to disable the keyboard in order to prevent any inadvertent actions resulting from accidental pressing of the keys. For mobile devices, this can happen if the device is put in a pocket or bumped while in a holster. This method can be used to disable the keyboard after a period of inactivity, or in response to a user action. Be sure to provide a way for the user to re-enable the keyboard (generally through the touch screen).
This method wraps the EnableHardwareKeyboard() function in the Windows CE APIs. For more detailed information, please see the MSDN documentation for this function at .
member.param: [in] Boolean value that specifies whether to enable or disable the keyboard. Set it to TRUE to enable the keyboard or FALSE to disable it.
member.returns: This method always returns TRUE.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.GetKeyboardStatus
member.summary: Returns the status of the hardware keyboard.
member.returns:
This function returns an value from the enumeration indicating whether or not a keyboard is present and what its capabilities are.
This method wraps the GetKeyboardStatus() function in the Windows CE APIs. For more information, please see the MSDN documentation on this function at .

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.MapVirtualKey(System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Translates, or maps, a virtual-key code into a scan code or character value, or translates a scan code into a virtual-key code.
member.remarks: This method wraps the MapVirtualKey() function from the Windows CE APIs. For more information, please see the MSDN documentation for this function at .
member.param: [in] Specifies the virtual-key code or scan code for a key.
[in] Specifies the translation to perform. The value of this parameter depends on the value of the uCode parameter
member.returns: A character value indicates success. Zero indicates that there is no translation.

member.summary: Determines the source of a keyboard message.
member.remarks: This method wraps the GetMessageSource() function from the Windows CE APIs. For more information, please see the MSDN documentation for this function at .

list.item: MSGSRC_SOFTWARE_POST indicates that the message source was software.
MSGSRC_HARDWARE_KEYBOARD indicates that the message source was the keyboard.
MSGSRC_UNKNOWN indicates that the message source is unknown.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.GetKeyboardLayout(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the active input language identifier for a specified thread.
member.remarks: This method wraps the GetKeyboardLayout() function in the Win CE .NET API. For more information on this function, see the MSDN documentation at . For more information about language identifiers, see Language Identifiers and Locales at in the Microsoft Windows CE .NET documentation in MSDN.
member.param: [in] Set to NULL to get the keyboard layout of the active thread. No other value is supported.
member.returns: The input language identifier for the thread indicates success. The low-order word contains a language identifier for the input language and the high-order word contains a device handle for the physical layout of the keyboard.

member.summary: Retrieves the name of the active keyboard layout.
member.remarks: This method wraps the GetKeyboardLayoutName() function in the Win CE .NET API. For more information on this function, please see the MSDN documentation at .
member.param: [in] Pointer to the buffer of at least KL_NAMELENGTH characters that is to receive the name of the keyboard layout, including the terminating null character.
member.returns: Nonzero indicates success. Zero indicates failure. To get extended error information, call GetLastError.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.DisableStandardShell
member.summary: Disables standard shell.
member.remarks: The standard shell refers to the Start button and the system tray. The task bar will still be available. The shell MUST be re-enabled before an application exits. Failure to re-enable the shell will leave the shell permanently disabled (until a warm boot or cold boot occurs), and will cause the task bar and icon tray to disappear.
member.returns: If successful returns true, otherwise false.
member.deprecated: This functions used undocumented Microsoft APIs that are not supported on newer operating systems. A new Kiosk Mode API is being developed to replace it.

members.member:
Enables Standard shell.
The standard shell refers to the Start button and the system tray. The task bar will still be available. The shell MUST be re-enabled before an application exits. Failure to re-enable the shell will leave the shell permanently disabled (until a warm boot or cold boot occurs), and will cause the task bar and icon tray to disappear. See also .
If successful returns true, otherwise false.
This functions used undocumented Microsoft APIs that are not supported on newer operating systems. A new Kiosk Mode API is being developed to replace it.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.InjectKeyboardCommand(PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Function,System.Int32,PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.CommandFlags)
member.summary: Simulates a key press.

remarks.p: This function is used to fake a keypress and release on a Psion Teklogix device. It does this by allowing an application to directly specify the results of a real keypress/release: a function code and its associated data (if any). The function code and data sent to the keyboard driver are handled directly (backlight up for example), or are converted into a sequence of keypress and release events.
Notes: 1. Injected keys follow all of the normal rules for real keypresses and releases, and are treated in exactly the same way.

2. An Injected modifier key follows the configured modes. (see also ). In other words, if an application injects the "Orange" key twice by specifying the Function.Orange function code, and the mode is "Off_Lock", then the Orange key modifier state will switch from Off to Lock and then back to off.
3. Invalid function codes and virtual key values are ignored.

example.p: 1. To change Orange modifier state to Lock:
2. To simulate the user pressing Shift-1:

member.param: The injected function code.
Data required by given function, if applicable
Operation flags.
member.exception: Thrown when device doesn't support this method
Thrown when driver fails to inject keyboard command.

member.name: E:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.LetterKeyCompletedEvent
member.summary: Some Psion Teklogix mobile computers have an Alpha mode, which allows letters to be typed using the numeric keys. For example, the letter B may be typed by locking down the Alpha key, then pressing the 2 key twice. While typing in letters in this manner, the task bar shows potential letters with each keypress. For example, pressing the 2 key the first time results in A showing in the task bar. Pressing it a second time results in B showing in the task bar. Pressing another key, or waiting for the timeout, clears this letter display and the last potential letter that was displayed is passed to the active application. The task bar feedback is important to the user since it indicates which letter is being typed. If your application hides the task bar, this important feedback is no longer visible. Your application may use this API in order to provide an equivalent feedback mechanism to the user. This API provides a way for users to know the potential letter with each keypress.

member.name: E:PsionTeklogix.Keyboard.Keyboard.LetterKeyProposedEvent
member.summary: Some Psion Teklogix mobile computers have an Alpha mode, which allows letters to be typed using the numeric keys. For example, the letter B may be typed by locking down the Alpha key, then pressing the 2 key twice. While typing in letters in this manner, the task bar shows potential letters with each keypress. For example, pressing the 2 key the first time results in A showing in the task bar. Pressing it a second time results in B showing in the task bar. Pressing another key, or waiting for the timeout, clears this letter display and the last potential letter that was displayed is passed to the active application. The task bar feedback is important to the user since it indicates which letter is being typed. If your application hides the task bar, this important feedback is no longer visible. Your application may use this API in order to provide an equivalent feedback mechanism to the user. This API provides a way for users to know when letter key is no longer the next potential key

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Peripherals.Peripherals
member.summary: The Peripherals class is used to manipulate peripherals, and device interfaces on a Windows CE-based device. Any peripheral that can be detected (and identified as a specific device) will be detectable through the Peripherals API. A device interface is a mechanism used by drivers to allow other software components to access to driver. When a device driver loads, it may choose to publish an interface. The interface may then be used to send commands to the driver.
member.remarks:
This class can be used in a polled fashion with the static members or in an event driven fashion by instantiating and binding the event handlers. The Peripherals class allows developers to perform the following operations:
Detect the presence of adapters and device interfaces. Using , it is possible to get a list of all device interfaces. Device interfaces will usually have a name like "XYZ1:", related to the device driver publishing them. It is also possible to detect if a specific device interface or peripheral is present.
Detect the presence of docking and tether port devices. Docking stations are separate hardware components such as battery chargers, portable docking modules, etc., and can possess extra serial, USB, or other communications ports. Tether port devices are usually peripheral devices such as serial scanners, RFID readers, etc.
Register for real-time notifications. By instantiating Peripherals class, developer gains access to and . By implementing event handlers developers will gaing access to information:
Tether Port Device Insertion (with the information about the type of tether port device)
Tether Port Device Removal (with the information about the type of tether port device)
Docking Station Insertion (with the information about the type of the docking station)
Docking Station Removal (with the information about the type of the docking station)

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Peripherals.Peripherals.SetPowerState(System.String,System.Int32)

summary.p: Sets the power state on the specified hardware port/slot/socket.

remarks.p: Once a slot etc. has been powered off it will remain powered off even if the Psion Teklogix device is cold-booted. A clean start of the Windows CE operating system will be required to power the slot back on (or a call to setPowerState). On a Pocket PC device, a cold-boot will cause the slot to be repowered. Removal and re-insertion of the card (or any card) will have no effect and will not be detected.

Powering off an empty slot/socket will only disable the detection of card insertions, as the slot/socket is not powered when empty. Powering on an empty slot has no effect, other than re-enabling detection of card insertion/removal.
Powering off the USB port may have no effect if the connected device has an external power source, as the port itself is not disabled, only the power supplied to the port is shut off.

Powering off a PCMCIA/SD-MMC/CF slot will have the same effect as a card removal, and will generate a card removal event. Powering on the PCMCIA/SD-MMC/CF slot will have the same effect as a card insertion, assuming there is a card present. A card insertion event will also be generated if a card is present.

It is not always possible to power off a slot/socket/port. For example, the SD-MMC slot on some 7535 terminals cannot be powered off. In such cases, the driver for the card in the slot/socket will be unloaded, and further activity on the slot or socket will be ignored. However, there is no guarantee the device in the slot or socket will actually be disabled, and if a radio is in the slot it may still be able to transmit.
A WORKABOUT PRO may or may not have a second PCMCIA slot. If it does not, attempting to enable/disable the slot will fail.
Not all Psion Teklogix devices have the peripherals listed below, and the power state may not be controllable on every device.
Valid hardware names that may be used in the 'Hardware' parameter are: * PCMCIA Slot0 * PCMCIA Slot1 * SD-MMC
Valid power states are: * PowerState_Off - power off the slot/socket/etc. * PowerState_On - power on the slot/socket/etc.

member.param: The port/slot/device whose power state is being changed.
The power state to set the slot/socket/etc. to.
member.returns: True if the socket/slot/port was powered off. False if the socket/slot/port could not be powered off.
member.exception: ArgumentException - Is throw when the supplied hardware component name is invalid, or found on this Psion Teklogix device.
ArgumentException - Is throw when the supplied hardware component name is null.
ApplicationException - Is thrown if the device is not ready, for example when repeatedly calling SetPowerState too quickly.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Peripherals.Peripherals.GetPowerState(System.String)

summary.p: Detects whether a given port/slot/socket is powered on or not.

remarks.p: Empty slots are not powered; they are in the POWERSTATE_OFF state.
The power state of some hardware components cannot be detected.
Not all Psion Teklogix devices have the peripherals listed below.
Valid hardware names that may be used in the 'Hardware' parameter are: * PCMCIA Slot0 * PCMCIA Slot1 * SD-MMC
Valid power states are: * PowerState_Off - power off the slot/socket/etc. * PowerState_On - power on the slot/socket/etc.

member.param: The port/slot/device to examine.
member.returns: The power state of the port/slot/device. Valid return codes are: * PowerState_Off - the slot etc. is powered off or the slot is empty * PowerState_On - the slot etc. is powered on * PowerState_Unknown - the powered state cannot be determined
member.exception: ArgumentException - Is throw when the supplied hardware component name is invalid, or found on this Psion Teklogix device.
ArgumentException - Is throw when the supplied hardware component name is null.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Peripherals.Peripherals.GetAdapterStatistics(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves the statistics for the specified adapter.

remarks.p: The following statistics are available for network adapters: * "Media State" - (connected/disconnected) * "RSSI" - Received Signal Strength Indicator (wireless adapters only) * "Channel" - current channel (wireless adapters only, and only available on some radio cards) * "SSID" - the network name (wireless adapters only) * "Access Point MAC address" - the MAC of the associated AP (wireless adapters only) * "Local MAC address" - MAC address of the radio / ethernet card * "Link Speed" - Current link speed being used by the radio / ethernet card * "Frame Size" - Current frame size in bytes * "Packet Size" - Current packet size in bytes * "Received Packets" - number of packets received by this adapter * "Transmitted Packets" - number of packets sent by this adapter * "Received Packet Errors" - number of bad packets received by this adapter * "Transmitted Packet Errors" - number of bad packets sent by this adapter

member.param: The name of the adapter whose statistics are to be retrieved. Must not be null.
member.exception: ArgumentException - Thrown when the device name is invalid.
ArgumentNullException - Thrown when the device name is null.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Peripherals.Bluetooth.PairSerialProfileDevice(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Pairs a Serial Port Profile Bluetooth device with this terminal. Use UnpairSerialProfileDevice() to remove the pairing.
Use PairSerialProfileScanner() to pair SPP Scanners.
Please note: the pairing will fail if a pairing already exists, unpair it first.
Developers note: Please make sure your application remembers the macAddress of the paired devices. The macAddress of the paired device is required to remove the pairing.
member.param: The MAC address of the Bluetooth device to pair with (expecting a string of exactly 12 hex digits, ex: "0016E3F019BB" ).
The security pin required by the Bluetooth device. Example "0000"
The port to be created and used for emulated serial connection. Example: "COM9:" Please note the required ':'.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Peripherals.Bluetooth.PairSerialProfileScanner(System.String,System.String,System.String)
member.summary:
Pairs a Serial Port Profile Bluetooth scanner with this terminal. Use UnpairSerialProfileDevice() to remove the pairing.
Please note: This method provides the same functionality as PairSerialProfileDevice() but will automatically notify Scanner Services about the newly paired scanner.
Please note: The pairing will fail if a pairing already exists, unpair it first.
Developers note: Please make sure your application remembers the macAddress of the paired devices. The macAddress of the paired device is required to remove the pairing.
member.param: The MAC address of the Bluetooth device to pair with (expecting a string of exactly 12 hex digits, Example: "0016E3F019BB" ).
The security pin required by the Bluetooth device. Example "0000"
The port to be created and used for emulated serial connection. Example: "COM9:" Please note the required ':'.

member.summary: Unpairs a Serial Port Profile Bluetooth device that was paired with either PairSerialProfileDevice() or PairSerialProfileScanner().

members.member:
@deprecated
The RegistryKey class is used to manipulate the WindowsCE Registry. It includes support for the following operations: * create a new registry key: new registry keys may be created underneath existing registry keys * open an existing registry key: an existing registry key can be opened, in order to read or write data to it * delete a registry key: existing registry keys and all the values underneath them can be removed from the registry * read registry values: existing registry values can be read from the registry * set registry values: registry name/value pairs can be added or changed * delete a registry value: existing registry values can be removed from the registry * key enumerations: the sub-keys and value names of a registry key can be listed * key counts: the number of values and sub-keys under a key can be counted
The RegistryKey class supports the following registry value types: * binary * integer * string * multi-string
All registry settings are located under one of 4 root keys: * CLASSES_ROOT * CURRENT_USER * LOCAL_MACHINE * USERS
Please note: the Configuration Namespace is deprecated. Use .NET Compact Framework 2.0 microsoft.win32 namespace instead.
Registry key strings use '\\' (a backslash) to delimit separate keys. Since backslash is used to generate escape characters, it must be doubled when placed within strings, and cannot be contained in a key name.
Registry key names are not case sensitive.
To get or set the default value for a particular registry key, specify a either a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic), or an empty string ("").
See the MSDN documentation on the WindowsCE Registry and registry keys for more information.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Configuration.RegistryKey.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor. Constructs a default RegistryKey object (not opened). The key cannot be used until either the Open method or the Create method is called.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Configuration.RegistryKey.Close
member.summary: The close method closes the registry key. All further operations on the Registry will fail until either the Open or Create method is called.

remarks.p: Calling the close method has no effect if the key is not open/valid.
Opening a registry key creates a registry handle, which prevents the actual registry key from being deleted. The key must be closed before it can be deleted.
Applications should call the Close method when finished using RegistryKey objects, in order to free up the resources associated with them.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Configuration.RegistryKey.Dispose
member.summary: Closes the registry key, and releases any resources it holds.
member.remarks: A key in the WindowsCE registry cannot be deleted until all registry key objects opened to the location in the registry are closed.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Configuration.RegistryKey.Create(PsionTeklogix.Configuration.RegistryKey,System.String)
member.summary: The Create method is used to create a new registry key. If the key already exists, it will be opened. If it does not exist, it will be created first (if possible).
member.exception: ArgumentNullException - If the KeyName parameter or the KeyRoot parameter is null.
ApplicationException - If creating or opening the registry key fails.

member.returns: A string array containing the names of the registry keys under the current registry key object.
member.exception: InvalidOperationException - If the registry key is not open/valid.
ApplicationException - If enumerating the subkeys of a registry key fails.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Configuration.RegistryKey.EnumerateValues
member.summary: The EnumerateValues method is used to retreive a list of all of the values associated with the open registry key. If no values are present, an empty Array is returned.
member.returns: An array containing the names of the registry values associated with the current registry key object. The value names are returned as strings.
member.exception: InvalidOperationException - If the registry key is not open/valid.
ApplicationException - If the values under the open registry key cannot be enumerated.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.Configuration.RegistryKey.EnumerateValueNamesAndData
member.summary: This method is used to retrieve a list of all of the values and the data associated with each value from the open registry key.

remarks.p: The values are returned as an array of RegistryValue objects. If no values are present, an empty vector is returned.
If the key has not been opened, an exception will be thrown.

member.returns: An array containing all the values under the open registry key.
member.exception: ApplicationException - If a list of values cannot be retrieved.
InvalidOperationException - If the RegistryKey is invalid (not open).

summary.p: The setMultiStringValue method is used to store a multi-string value in the the Registry using an open registry key. Multi-strings in C++ are represented as a sequence of null-terminated strings, with the final string terminated by 2 nulls to indicate the end of the multi-string. As this is not possible in .NET, multi-strings are instead represented by MultiString objects.

remarks.p: If the multi-string value is null, an exception will be thrown.
If the key has not been opened, an exception will be thrown.
If no name is given (i.e. the key name is null or blank) the value will be stored as the default key value.

member.param: The name of the value to set.
The multistring data to store in the registry.
member.exception: ArgumentNullException - If the value parameter is null.
InvalidOperationException - If registry key has not been opened.
ApplicationException - If the supplied registry key value cannot be set or changed.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.Configuration.RegistryKey.RegistryValue
member.summary: The RegistryValue class is used to report registry values read from the Registry with the enumerateValues method.

remarks.p: The name member will contain the name of the associated registry value, and can be null or blank if the value is the default key value.

The value parameter will contain the value read from the registry, as one of four types: * Integer - for all integer values, including big and little endian values. Note that big/little endian values will be converted to the correct endianess before being returned to the application. * ByteArrayObject - for all binary values. * MultiString - for all multistrings. * String - for all strings.

member.summary: Finalizer method. Dispose of all managed and unmanaged resources.
member.remarks: This function must be called explicitly by the application (via the device interface's Dispose() method. The reason for this is that CF 1.0 does not support background threads. That means that the garbage collector will not run because there is an active foreground thread (workerThread). Unfortunately the thread will not be terminated until the Dispose method is called.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.AccessFlags
member.summary: Flags used to control access to various WWAN operations.
member.remarks: Some WWAN operations performed by an application could conflict with similar operations performed by the WWAN user interface (WWANUI). In order to prevent these operations from causing problems, an application is normally prevented from performing them. If an application needs to perform one of these operations, for example changing the PIN, it must first request access to the operation. Doing so will prevent the WWAN UI from performing the disabled operation, or reacting to the operation being performed by another application.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.IndicationsListener
member.summary: The IndicationsListener class defines the interface to be implemented by applications that require notification when indications are generated by the NDIS driver.
member.remarks:
In order to receive indications, an application must:
Implement the IndicationsListener interface.
Register itself with the WirelessWAN class using the SetIndicationsListener method.
Enable indications using the SetIndicationsState method.
An application can temporarily disable indications by calling the method WirelessWAN::SetIndicationsState, with the parameter set to false.
An application must disable indications before terminating by calling the method WirelessWAN::SetIndicationsState, with the parameter set to false.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.IndicationsListener.OnReadyState(PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WWAN_READY_STATE)
member.summary: This indication is generated when the ready state of the driver changes.

remarks.p: Barring a catastrophic failure, ready state indications should only be received at start-up and shutdown. Note that the start-up timing depends on the type of modem.

member.param: The ready state information.

member.param: The signal state information.

member.param: The current PIN state settings.

member.name: T:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN
member.summary: This class is used to perform all Wireless Wide Area Networking- related operations.

remarks.p:
The WirelessWAN class is used to perform all Wireless Wide Area Networking-related operations and activities, including:
* Registering to receive indications * Getting the capabilities of the installed WWAN modem * Getting the WWAN driver version (major and minor) * Getting the operational state of the device (ready state, PIN state, and registration state) * Listing all available networks * Changing, enabling, disabling, or submitting the PIN. * Setting provisioned contexts * Changing the signal strength settings (interval and threshold) * Reading SMS messages * Deleting SMS messages * Getting the SMS capabilities of the modem * Sending SMS messages * Setting the SMS configuration * Retrieving the SMS configuration

When an application calls a WirelessWAN method, it should first check the return code of the function - this value determines whether or not the request was successfully issued to the driver. If the method returned successfully, the application should then check the resultCode member of the WWanRequestParameters structure to determine the results of the operation.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.Initialize
member.summary: Initializes the WirelessWAN API.
member.remarks: The Initialize method initializes the WirelessWAN API for use by applications. This method must be called before any other API methods have been called.
member.returns: * WwanRequest.DriverNotRunning - If the WWAN driver is not running. * WwanRequest.Failure - If the API did not initialize properly. * WwanRequest.Success - If the API initialized successfully.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.Shutdown
member.summary: Shuts down the WirelessWAN API.
member.remarks: This method must be called before the application exits.
member.returns: * WwanRequest.Success - If the API was successfully shutdown.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.GetCurrentAccessFlags(PsionTeklogix.WWAN.AccessFlags@)
member.summary: Returns the current set of flags representing the restricted SMS operations currently reserved for use by applications.
member.remarks: The GetCurrentAccessFlags method returns the current set of flags representing the restricted SMS operations currently reserved for use by applications.
member.param: The current set of operations not be performed by the WWAN user interface (WWANUI).
member.returns: The status of the request: * WwanRequest.Success - If the operation was successful. * WwanRequest.NotInitialized - If the Initialize method was not called or failed.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.SetCurrentAccessFlags(PsionTeklogix.WWAN.AccessFlags)
member.summary: Modifies the set of access flags used to control access to the restricted operations listed in the AccessFlags enumeration.

remarks.p: When calling this method, one or more access flags may be supplied. These flags allow the application to access several operations normally reserved for the WWAN user interface (WWANUI.exe), while at the same time preventing the WWANUI itself from performing them. Take care when using these operations, especially the Set PIN operation, as setting an invalid value(s) could prevent the modem from functioning properly.
An application calling this method should take care to save the old set of access flags and restore them on exit.

An application should NOT simply change access flags, perform an operation, and then reset the flags. Under most circumstances, the application should modify the flags at startup, and reset them on exit.

member.param: Specifies the set of reserved operations to be performed by the application. Set the parameter value to zero if no reserved operations are required by the application.
member.returns: The status of the request: * WwanRequest.Success - If the operation was successful. * WwanRequest.NotInitialized - If the Initialize method was not called or failed.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.SetIndicationsListener(PsionTeklogix.WWAN.IndicationsListener)
member.summary: Registers the specified object to receive indications sent by the WWAN driver.
member.remarks: The SetIndicationsListener method registers the specified object to receive indications sent by the WWAN driver. Indications will only be sent if the SetIndicationsState method is called with a value of 'true'.
member.param: The object to register to receive indications. The parameter can be null, if so indications will not be generated, regardless of whether indications are enabled.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.SetIndicationsState(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Enables or disables indications.
member.remarks: The SetIndicationsState method enables or disables the generation of indications. It must be called with a value of 'true' in order to enable indications.
member.param: If true, indications will be enabled. If false, indications will not be generated.

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.GetDeviceCaps(PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WWAN_DEVICE_CAPS)
member.summary: This method is used to query the capabilities of the WWAN modem.
member.remarks: The GetDeviceCaps method is used to query the capabilities of the WWAN modem, including the cellular technology, the classes of packet data supported, the type of voice service provided, and whether a SIM is used.
member.param: A WWAN_DEVICE_CAPS object.
member.returns: The status of the request: * WwanRequest.InvalidParameter - If the caps parameter was 0 (NULL). * WwanRequest.NotInitialized - If the Initialize method was not called or failed. * WwanRequest.Failure - If the request could not be issued. * WwanRequest.Success - If the request was successful. * WwanRequest.OutOfMemory - If a memory allocation failure occurred * WwanRequest.BufferTooSmall - If an internal buffer was too small * WwanRequest.AccessDenied - If the driver is in an invalid state to handle the request

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.GetReadyState(PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WWanRequestParameters,PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WWAN_READY_STATE)
member.summary: The method allows the application to retrieve the ready state of the WWAN driver.
member.remarks: The GetReadyState method allows the application to retrieve the ready state of the WWAN driver. It also allows the driver to report other related information, such as the subscriber and equipment identity, and associated ISDNs (phone numbers).
member.param: The request parameters for the request.
A WWAN_READY_STATE object.
member.returns: * WwanRequest.InvalidParameter - If the readyState parameter was 0 (NULL). * WwanRequest.NotInitialized - If the Initialize method was not called or failed. * WwanRequest.Failure - If the request could not be issued. * WwanRequest.Success - If the request was successful. * WwanRequest.EventHandleInvalid - If the event handle in the params structure is invalid. * WwanRequest.OutOfMemory - If a memory allocation failure occurred * WwanRequest.BufferTooSmall - If an internal buffer was too small * WwanRequest.AccessDenied - If the driver is in an invalid state to handle the request

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.GetPinState(PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WWanRequestParameters,PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WWAN_PIN_STATE)
member.summary: Returns the password/PIN state, primarily indicating when a PIN needs to be entered.

remarks.p: The GetPinState method is used to retrieve the PIN state, primarily to determine if the PIN/PUK needs to be entered.
The GetPinState method will fail if the modem does not support a SIM, as is the case with most CDMA modems. Use the GetDeviceCaps method to determine if the modem supports a SIM.

member.param: The request parameters for the request.
The current PIN state settings.
member.returns: * WwanRequest.NotInitialized - If the Initialize method was not called or failed. * WwanRequest.Failure - If the request could not be issued. * WwanRequest.Success - If the request was successful. * WwanRequest.EventHandleInvalid - If the event handle in the params structure is invalid. * WwanRequest.OutOfMemory - If a memory allocation failure occurred * WwanRequest.BufferTooSmall - If an internal buffer was too small * WwanRequest.AccessDenied - If the driver is in an invalid state to handle the request

member.name: M:PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WirelessWAN.SetPin(PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WWanRequestParameters,PsionTeklogix.WWAN.WWAN_SET_PIN)
member.summary: This method is used to change the PIN settings on a SIM card.

remarks.p: The SetPin method is used to send a PIN to the device, enable or disable PIN settings, or change a PIN on the SIM.
The SetPin method will fail if the modem does not support a SIM, as is the case with for most CDMA modems. Use the GetDeviceCaps method to determine if the modem supports a SIM.
All PIN operations require that a valid PIN be supplied. If too many invalid PIN values are sent in a row, the SIM will be disabled until a valid PUK is entered.

The SetPin method is a restricted operation. The method call will fail with the WwanRequest.AccessFlagNotSet error if the appropriate access flag has not been set using the SetCurrentAccessFlags method.

member.param: The request parameters for the request.
The new PIN settings.
member.returns: * WwanRequest.NotInitialized - If the Initialize method was not called or failed. * WwanRequest.Failure - If the request could not be issued. * WwanRequest.Success - If the request was successful. * WwanRequest.EventHandleInvalid - If the event handle in the params structure is invalid. * WwanRequest.OutOfMemory - If a memory allocation failure occurred * WwanRequest.BufferTooSmall - If an internal buffer was too small * WwanRequest.AccessDenied - If the driver is in an invalid state to handle the request
